{"position": null, "sentence": "A meaningful relationship was noted between estimated ad valence and the forgottenness rate (Pearson \u03c1 = 0.45, p < 0.05)", "statisticType": "cspearman", "record": {"doF": null, "pcor": "0.45", "pval": "0.05"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Information from social sources can be particularly critical when navigating novel, ambiguous, risky, or high-consequence environments.  More generally, there is evidence that incentive structures  may shape people's predictive and decision-making behavior\u00a0<cit.>.  While people's use of information from other humans  is shaped by homophily and perceived costs,  it is unknown whether people conceptualize algorithms  in ways that would produce similar influences  (though see lu2021human).  Both of these factors can be characterized in information-theoretic terms,  so they plausibly might extend to algorithms as well.  We thus conducted an experiment that explicitly manipulated these factors  in the human-AI interaction context, including measures of decisions and perceptions.                                    The two measures of likelihood judgments\u2014Likert scale and probability slider\u2014were highly correlated (\u03c1=0.77, p<0.001)", "statisticType": "cspearman", "record": {"doF": null, "pcor": "0.77", "pval": "0.001"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Participants also provided the motivations behind their choices.  For example, in anomaly detection task, P4 said: \u201cGiven that the source visualization is a scatterplot, I will add color encoding to find more patterns at first\u201d.  P18 noted that\u201cif the values are aggregated in Y axis, I would remove the aggregation to retrieve more details for anomaly detection.\u201d P20 commented: \u201cfor me, line charts may not be a good choice for revealing anomalies, so I change the line chart to a scatter plot.\u201d  Table\u00a0<ref> shows that the chart design choice recommended by Task-Only also strongly correlates with user preference, with \u03c4_b=0.51, p=0.039 and \u03c1=0.66, p=0.038", "statisticType": "cspearman", "record": {"doF": null, "pcor": "0.66", "pval": "0.038"}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}
